headline: Money men are over the moon and on to satellites
text: Thirty years ago the world - or at least those with access to a television set - watched Neil Armstrong walk on the moon. Since then a select band has followed in his footsteps. Space-based research has become a reality. There is talk of putting the hotel business into orbit. But, despite the huge publicity generated by Armstrong and company, the space industry is still not a people-carrying business. The profits lie elsewhere - primarily with satellites; those who build, launch and insure them; and those whose services are carried by them.

headline: Rhyme, reason and depression
text: Thirty years after the American poet Sylvia Plath killed herself in London, the literary row over why she died is still going on. While some feminists claim that Plath was the victim of an insensitive husband, she is also accused of trying to manipulate the world around her once too often. But the doctor who cared for her in the last weeks of her life claims that the debate overlooks the real villian, and the subject of most of her poems and diary - the depression that dogged her life.

headline: Frank confessions
text:
Frank McCourt looks out over his land, a fugitive from a life sentence handed down for a crime he did not commit. The writer says he is tired of himself, bored telling the story of his life. 
He has been carrying Angela's Ashes, the weight of his pitiful childhood, for all his 69 years and now he wants to wander down different literary lanes. But that story has paid him back, late in life, with more than a certain sadness.

headline: A born-again writer
text: The problem for the biographer of Sartre is that he wrote an autobiography. Words (Les Mots) was written in the 1950s, then revised and published in 1963. It is, as everyone agrees, a magnificent piece of writing and it earned him the Nobel Prize for literature which he refused to accept. All his biographers complain that the autobiography ceases when the author is only 11 years old, but they seek to find clues in it. They dwell on the special period, that of Paradise.

headline: At Auden's birthday party
text: I attended WH Auden's 50th birthday party. He lived in St Mark's Place in the East Village with his companion Chester Kallman in a walk-up flat. In the bathroom the bathtub was filled with champagne cooling in ice and surrounded by a dirty bath water ring. One room had a wall with a sinister bulge the size and shape of a man walled up in it. Assorted poets were all drinking Auden's health.

headline: Knowledge is power
text: John Hannah. Now there's a man not to play at Trivial Pursuit. Not only must he know all about ancient Egypt, Ruben Carter's boxing career, police procedures in Scotland and WH Auden, he's also got an encyclopedic knowledge of natural history. Barely a week goes by without him explaining how starlings flock together or describing the movement of lava flows and glaciers on some nature programme or another. If you watched The Discovery Channel for long enough, you could probably pretend you were going out with him. But caught between Hannah and Bill Paterson, you'd end up hobbling round that Trivial Pursuit board with only a humiliated grimace and no pieces of pie.

headline: When Auden ceased to fear
text: Although his biographer Edward Mendelson never really admits it here, there were two WH Audens, not one. The pre-war Auden, about whom Mendelson wrote in his study Early Auden, was a world-class figure - a major poet quarrelling memorably with the ugliness and mendacity of his era, in language which seemed a model of lucid, new-minted modernity. He coined a phrase for the 30s -"a low dishonest decade" - which is still used, and, in literary terms, our memories of the Weimar period continue to be conditioned by the imprint of the raffishness and anger with which he wrote and thought.

headline: Babes in limbo land
text: Ballet companies aren't in the habit of dedicating triple bills to one choreographer's work - which is why the Royal's all-MacMillan programme makes such an impact. By juxtaposing three works from three different periods we're not only given an overview of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's huge range; we're also reminded of how compulsively theatrical his instincts were, even when making ballets with no apparent plots. Concerto (1966), Rituals (1975) and Gloria (1980) have no stories to tell, yet all of them beckon us into narrative. Even Concerto - a Balanchine-influenced setting of Shostakovich's second piano concerto - has at its heart a pas de deux of intriguing, elusive romance. Gloria looks most like a story ballet in that its staging takes us directly into the wastelands of the second world war, yet it contains no images of fighting. MacMillan suspends the frank athleticism of his dancers' moves within a kind of otherworldly trance, creating a meditation on the limbo land between life and death.
